div.p: From Frederick Bailey to William Thiselton-Dyer
Letter press copy book 2, p. 469, Queensland Herbarium, Brisbane.

To proof.
An extensive search at RBG Kew has failed to find the original version of this letter. The text given here is a portion only of a longer letter dated 3 July 1893.
[...]

Now just a few words re the preparation of the supplementary volume to Benthams Flora Australiensis
Bentham (1863-78).
by complying with the wish of my friends, who take an interest in the indigenous plants, to prepare such a volume I have incurred the [vengeance] of the mighty Baron. I sent to him one of my circulars upon the subject
See F. Bailey to M, March 1893 (in this edition as 93-00-00b). M complained that the circular was issued without first consulting him; see for example, M to W. Thiselton-Dyer, 21 March 1893, and M to J. Hooker, 28 March 1893. For the context of Bailey's proposal, see Clements (1998), and for M's failure to pubish a supplement, see Lucas (2003). of this he took no notice to me but wrote to his friends in the different colonies complaining of my having dared to interfere
See for example, M to O. Tepper, 2 April 1893; with his [...], and [...] friends [...] [...] friends [...] have written to my friends in the strongest manner, at last the Baron wrote to me in a sort of [...] style, stating that he, only, had the right to publish the work.
M to F. Bailey, 31 May 1893, in a letter responding to a different matter raised in F. Bailey to M, 25 May 1893. This I [...] for the Flora was paid for by the [...] colonies conjointly therefore I [...] [...] any government botanist in these colonies has a perfect right to prepare a supplementary volume. I however stated that I only had agreed to prepare the work, because of the determined way in which he had set his [...] to destroy the excellent work of Bentham
M had in his Systematic Census (B83.03.04, B89.12.03) disrupted the group Monochlamydeae used by Bentham, because he thought it produced an unnatural arrangement; he also argued for this change in other publications (see Maroske (2006)). which I with a large number of other botanic workers in these colonies so much admired — But that even now if he would undertake to prepare a volume — using the same system and nomenclature and not as hitherto ignore my work I would gladly leave the work to him
M had evidently agreed, in a now lost letter of 8 June to Bailey (see F. Bailey to M, 14 June 1893), to follow the arrangement of Flora Australiensis; he had already done so earlier in M to W. Thiselton-Dyer, 15 May 1893. M certainly omitted several of Bailey's species that he thought could not be admitted into his Census (B89.12.03) until 'confirmed by observations of my own' (M to R. Tate, 15 October 1889), since he thought many were 'untenable' (M to W. Thiselton-Dyer, 19 February 1890). for I have plenty to do in working up the flora of Queensland.
Bailey was at this time publishing Bailey (1889-1905), as well as his Botany Bulletin (for example Bailey (1893)). [...] in the [...] volume must appear with descriptions all named varieties of the various australian species, as well as all the plants which have been noticed as having become naturalized [...]
one and a half lines illegible.

My friends blame me for giving up and probably I may not have acted wisely but I did not wish anything [...]
illegible words.
Bentham unfortunately [...] [...] the Baron and he has a greater love of self aggrandizement than botany [...]
several illegible lines.
for none in my opinion [...] [...] Bentham so much do I admire him that when describing a new species I try to closely copy his style and language as you may have noticed [...]
several illegible lines.
